description: cream-colored leather cover; two pairs of green ties on outer edge; book of 43 engraved plates; artist's copy book with images of faces and facial features, feet, hands, arms and torsos

text: Drawing manuals like these two examples were common teaching tools for artists and amateurs learning to draw in the 16th and 17th centuries. The prints offer patterns for the aspiring draftsman to copy, with isolated body parts—eyes, ears, noses, hands, arms, feet, legs, torsos—and concise figure and animal designs. Mastering the simple forms presented in these books, which also introduced conventions of foreshortening and proportion, was an important first step in learning the art of drawing.
title: Il vero modo et ordine per dissegnar tutte le parti et membra del corpo humano.
